texts.shortText:
Strange, transparent, planktonic animals found in surface waters worldwide. Resemble tiny tadpoles (or giant sperm cells!), with a long flat, flexible tail and a small sea-squirt-like body attached at right angles to the tail and containing the organs. Usually surrounded by much larger, delicate spherical mucus ‘houses’ used to capture food.

South African species are little studied and it is not possible to allocate specific names to regional species, certainly not on the basis of photographic images. Since several genera and at least 19 species in the family Oikopleuridae have broad global distributions it is, however, likely that a number of different species occur in South Africa waters.
Body about 5 mm long (excluding tail), house up to the size of a golf ball (other much larger larvaceans occur in other genera).

Global: Not identified to species, but genus widespread globally.

Local/Regional: Throughout region (may be different species in different areas, but not identified to species level).

Common planktonic species, but small and fragile, so seldom noticed and usually damaged if caught with conventional plankton nets. A current is generated thought the house by beating of the elongate flattened tail. The house is replaced several times a day and discarded houses may form an important component of marine snow, which sinks slowly to the ocean floor and supports many deep-sea benthic organisms. Some larvaceans are bioluminescent.

Secretes a remarkable mucus house through which it pumps water by beating the large, flattened tail. The house has a course mesh on the incurrent side to strain out large particles and a much finer mesh to retain fine organic particles, down to the size of bacteria, on the other, exhalent side. Food collected on this sieve is constantly transported to the mouth. Very fine particles can be captured, allowing larvaceans to feed on minute particles as small as bacteria and unavailable to other filter-feeders with more conventional feeding organs (like gills). Once the house gets clogged with filtered material the entire structure is discarded and sinks slowly to the ocean floor and a new one is constructed. This happens several times a day!

Reproduction is sexual, eggs and sperm being released into the water. Fertilised eggs develop into tadpole larvae and the tail moves from the rear to the side of the body as these metamorphose into the adult form.

Larvaceans are unlikely to be confused with other groups, but other families and genera are also found in the region, including some (possibly genus Bathochordaeus) that make a large circular, pleated house resembling at transparent croissant!

Fenaux R, Bone, Q & Deibel, D (1998). Appendicularian distribution and zoogeography. In Q. Bone [ed.], The biology of pelagic tunicates. Oxford University Press, Oxford.

Gibbons, MJ (1997). An introduction to the Zooplankton of the Benguela Current Region. NBD Goodwood, Western Cape.

Jaspers, C, Nielsen, TG, Carstensen, J, Hopcroft, RR & Møller, EF (2009). Metazooplankton distribution across the Southern Indian Ocean with emphasis on the role of larvaceans. Journal of Plankton Research, 31(5), 525-540.
